title: Football: Pompton Lakes' rally comes up just short
text:
Buy this photo Photo by Sandy Stucki Nick Posimato's highlight reel catch gave the Cardinals a chance to complete a remarkable come from behind win but they were not able to finish to comeback. 
HAWTHORNE – On Friday night the Pompton Lakes Cardinals traveled to Hawthorne to take on the Bears in a rivalry game that had huge implications on the line. 
In the first half both defense's were impressive while the two offensive units seemed to be stuck in neutral and the game headed to the halftime break tied 0-0. 
Over the first 24 minutes of play the Bears compiled only 100 total yards while turning the ball over once but that was even better then the Cardinals who had just 38 yards of offense, and had committed a pair of turnovers, in the first two quarters. 
"We could not find out way on offense and every time that we did something good we started going the other way," said Pompton Lakes head coach Scott Mahoney. "It happens and that is what we have to fight through." 
Pompton Lakes finally broke out of the games offensive doldrums on their second possession of the second half. 
Will Verrico got the drive going when he returned a Hawthorne punt 29-yards down to the Bears' 38-yard line. 
Chris Grecco did the rest from there as he took a handoff from Kevin Cotter and sprinted 38-yards for the score and when combined with Chris Hester's extra point Pompton Lakes lead 7-0 early in the third quarter. 
The lead would be short lived though as Hawthorne answered right back on a 19-yard TD pass from Ryan VanderWerf to Dave Mascis. The extra point tied the score at seven midway through the quarter. 
A pair of sacks would end the Cardinals next two offensive possessions but there was nothing that the Pompton Lakes defense could do to stop the Bears attack as Hawthorne jumped ahead 19-7 midway through the fourth quarter. 
A long return by Cole Harriet coupled with a personal foul on Hawthorne gave the Cardinals the ball at midfield after the third Hawthorne touchdown. 
After another Hawthorne penalty moved the ball to the Bears 35-yard line the Cardinals quickly went in the wrong decision. 
A holding penalty cost the Cardinals 16 yards as they went from a first and ten at the 12 yard line to a second and 23 at the Bears' 25 yard line. 
The Cardinals would eventually be facing a fourth and 19 from the 21 but they were able to convert as Cotter hit Nick Posimato on a post pattern. 
The junior receiver made a spectacular catch and with the extra point the Cardinals were within 19-14. 
The Bears were able to move into Pompton Lakes side of the field on their ensuing drive but the Cardinals held firm and forced Hawthorne to turn the ball over on downs giving the Cardinals one last chance to go for the win. 
The chance would go for naught as the Bears defense did not give up a first down and they were able to run out the clock. 
"We had our shot, it just came up a little short," said Mahoney. "It should not have gotten to that point but it has two games in a row. When we break through that little area then the attitude changes and we have to figure out a way to break through that." 
Pompton Lakes (2-2) will now have to refocus as they prepare to host Palisades Park next Saturday at 1:00 p.m. 
"We don't control any destiny at this point we just control what we do next week," said Mahoney.
